item.title: Common Lead Test Can Give False Results, FDA Warns
item.description: May 17, 2017 - Common blood tests for lead can give falsely-low results in certain cases, according to a new warning from the Food and Drug Administration.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 17, 2017 - Common blood tests for lead can give falsely-low results in certain cases, according to a new warning from the Food and Drug Administration. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/17/528793444/common-lead-test-can-give-false-results-fda-warns

item.title: Ethics Of Aid: Should Donated Health Dollars Go To 'Children First'?
item.description: May 17, 2017 - That's how health aid is now allocated in the developing world. Should more money go to old people with chronic diseases? Our audience shares their views.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 17, 2017 - That's how health aid is now allocated in the developing world. Should more money go to old people with chronic diseases? Our audience shares their views. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/05/17/528620977/ethics-of-aid-should-donated-health-dollars-go-to-children-first

item.title: A Tale Of Four Famines
item.description:
May 17, 2017 - Climate and conflict have left millions with little to no access to food in Somalia, South Sudan, Nigeria and Yemen.
- http://the1a.org/shows/2017-05-17/a-tale-of-four-famines
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 17, 2017 - Climate and conflict have left millions with little to no access to food in Somalia, South Sudan, Nigeria and Yemen. http://the1a.org/shows/2017-05-17/a-tale-of-four-famines

item.title: Secret To Maine's Touted High-Risk Pool? Enough Money
item.description: May 17, 2017 - GOP legislators say Maine's "invisible high-risk pool" was a good model for how to insure people who have pre-existing conditions. Critics say Maine's program was much better funded than the GOP plan.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 17, 2017 - GOP legislators say Maine's "invisible high-risk pool" was a good model for how to insure people who have pre-existing conditions. Critics say Maine's program was much better funded than the GOP plan. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/17/527960631/the-idea-the-gop-s-health-care-bill-borrows-from-maine

item.title: Food To Cure What Ails You: When Cookbooks Treated Meals As Medicine
item.description: May 17, 2017 - At the turn of the 20th century, when access to professional care was spotty, many cookbooks served up recipes for the sick — some (brandy) more appealing than others (toast water).
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 17, 2017 - At the turn of the 20th century, when access to professional care was spotty, many cookbooks served up recipes for the sick — some (brandy) more appealing than others (toast water). http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/17/528123967/food-to-cure-what-ails-you-when-cookbooks-treated-meals-as-medicine

item.title: From A Millennial To Her Peers: Want to Help The Underserved? Sign Up For Insurance
item.description: May 17, 2017 - A law student was touched when she had a seizure during a big exam and classmates dropped everything to help. But if you really want to help sick people, she says, "you'll sign up for health care."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 17, 2017 - A law student was touched when she had a seizure during a big exam and classmates dropped everything to help. But if you really want to help sick people, she says, "you'll sign up for health care." http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/17/527416507/hey-millennials-want-to-help-the-underserved-sign-up-for-insurance

item.title: Texas Wants Medicaid Funds, Right To Keep Planned Parenthood From Getting Any
item.description: May 16, 2017 - In 2011, the state gave up millions in federal Medicaid funding so it could exclude the chain of clinics, which counts abortion among the procedures it provides, from its women's health program.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - In 2011, the state gave up millions in federal Medicaid funding so it could exclude the chain of clinics, which counts abortion among the procedures it provides, from its women's health program. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/16/528657247/texas-wants-medicaid-funds-right-to-keep-planned-parenthood-from-getting-any

item.title: How Many Teenagers Die Each Day ... And Why
item.description:
May 16, 2017 - A new report from the World Health Organization looks at the causes — and how most of the deaths could be prevented.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/05/16/528643258/how-many-teenagers-die-each-day-and-why
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - A new report from the World Health Organization looks at the causes — and how most of the deaths could be prevented. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/05/16/528643258/how-many-teenagers-die-each-day-and-why

item.title: Candidates Confront GOP Health Care Bill In Montana Special Election
item.description: May 16, 2017 - Health care is on the minds of many potential voters in Montana, but the House health bill itself is unlikely to sway entrenched Republican voters in the special election next week.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - Health care is on the minds of many potential voters in Montana, but the House health bill itself is unlikely to sway entrenched Republican voters in the special election next week. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/16/528598340/candidates-confront-gop-health-care-bill-in-montana-special-election

item.title: An Experiment Helps Heroin Users Test Their Street Drugs For Fentanyl
item.description: May 16, 2017 - Some people on heroin die because the drug was laced with something much stronger — like fentanyl. A few needle exchange programs give users test strips to check their drug's content before injecting.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - Some people on heroin die because the drug was laced with something much stronger — like fentanyl. A few needle exchange programs give users test strips to check their drug's content before injecting. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/16/527924429/an-experiment-helps-heroin-users-test-their-street-drugs-for-fentanyl

item.title: Why Are Americans Drinking Less Cow's Milk? Its Appeal Has Curdled
item.description: May 16, 2017 - In the 1900s, nutritionists and dairy producers helped convince Americans that cow's milk was nature's perfect food. But the science and tastes have changed, and we're guzzling much less than before.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - In the 1900s, nutritionists and dairy producers helped convince Americans that cow's milk was nature's perfect food. But the science and tastes have changed, and we're guzzling much less than before. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/16/528460207/why-are-americans-drinking-less-cows-milk-its-appeal-has-curdled

item.title: Pet Rat In Vancouver Overdoses On Heroin, Saved By Narcan
item.description: May 16, 2017 - Snuggles ate some heroin, according to the woman who brought the little rodent into an overdose prevention site in Canada. Volunteers administered a drug that reverses opioid overdoses.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - Snuggles ate some heroin, according to the woman who brought the little rodent into an overdose prevention site in Canada. Volunteers administered a drug that reverses opioid overdoses. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/16/528622327/pet-rat-in-vancouver-overdoses-on-heroin-saved-by-narcan

item.title: Price's Remarks On Opioid Treatment Were Unscientific And Damaging, Experts Say
item.description: May 16, 2017 - Nearly 700 experts signed a letter to HHS Secretary Tom Price asking that he correct remarks in which he called medication-assisted treatment for addiction "substituting one opioid for another."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - Nearly 700 experts signed a letter to HHS Secretary Tom Price asking that he correct remarks in which he called medication-assisted treatment for addiction "substituting one opioid for another." http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/16/528614422/prices-remarks-on-opioid-treatment-were-unscientific-and-damaging-experts-say

item.title: Trump Refusal to 'Bail Out' Insurers Might End Up Making Policies Cheaper
item.description: May 16, 2017 - It's a weird twist: If the government refuses to reimburse insurance companies for cost-sharing subsidies, it could make health insurance a lot cheaper for people buying on the exchanges in 2018.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - It's a weird twist: If the government refuses to reimburse insurance companies for cost-sharing subsidies, it could make health insurance a lot cheaper for people buying on the exchanges in 2018. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/16/528584408/trump-refusal-to-bail-out-insurers-might-end-up-making-policies-cheaper

item.title: GOP Health Bill Penalizes Patients Who Let Insurance Lapse
item.description: May 16, 2017 - In some states, a break in health coverage of more than 63 days would let insurers charge premiums of any price for a year — putting health insurance out of reach for many sick people, analysts say.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - In some states, a break in health coverage of more than 63 days would let insurers charge premiums of any price for a year — putting health insurance out of reach for many sick people, analysts say. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/16/528508443/gop-health-bill-penalizes-patients-who-let-insurance-lapse
